title: 3.3: Attractors
summary: Learn to create particle attractors that pull particles toward specific points in space
intro: In this lesson, you'll learn how to use UpdateAttractorBlock to create attractors that pull particles toward specific points in space. Attractors are useful for creating effects like particles being pulled toward a black hole, magnetic fields, or gravitational wells. You'll learn to set attractor position, strength, and combine attractors with other effects.
steps: Create a SystemBlock - this is the root of your particle system
Create a CreateParticleBlock to emit particles
Set an initial color and size using ParticleInputBlock
Add a <filter-value>BoxShape</filter-value> block to emit particles from a box volume
Add UpdateAttractorBlock to modify particle direction (must come before UpdatePositionBlock)
Create an attractor position using ParticleConverterBlock (X, Y, Z coordinates)
Set the attractor strength (higher values = stronger pull)
Connect the attractor position to UpdateAttractorBlock's attractor input
Connect the strength value to UpdateAttractorBlock's strength input
Add UpdatePositionBlock after UpdateAttractorBlock for basic movement
The attractor modifies particle direction first, then position is updated based on the modified direction

blocks.name: UpdateAttractorBlock
blocks.description: Creates an attractor effect that pulls particles toward a specific point in 3D space. The force decreases with distance squared, creating realistic physics behavior.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The display name of the block

properties.name: attractor
properties.description: The position of the attractor in 3D space (X, Y, Z coordinates)

properties.name: strength
properties.description: The strength of the attraction force. Higher values create stronger pull. The force is inversely proportional to distance squared.

blocks.name: ParticleConverterBlock (Vector3)
blocks.description: Creates a Vector3 from individual X, Y, Z float values. Used to define the attractor position.

properties.name: xIn, yIn, zIn
properties.description: Individual float inputs for X, Y, Z components

codeCopy: This lesson demonstrates attractor physics. An attractor creates a force that pulls particles toward a target point. The formula for the force is: force = (strength / distance²) * direction, where direction is the normalized vector from particle to attractor. This creates realistic behavior where particles close to the attractor experience strong pull, while distant particles experience weaker pull. Attractors are useful for creating effects like particles orbiting a center, being drawn to a target, or creating vortex-like patterns.
objectives: Understand how UpdateAttractorBlock creates attractive forces
Set attractor position using Vector3 coordinates
Control attractor strength to adjust pull intensity
Understand inverse square law for distance-based force
Combine attractors with other physics effects

commonMistakes.mistake: Using wrong coordinate system for attractor position
commonMistakes.explanation: Attractor position uses 3D coordinates (X, Y, Z). Using 2D coordinates or wrong axis orientation places the attractor in the wrong location.
commonMistakes.solution: Use ParticleConverterBlock with xIn, yIn, zIn to create Vector3 for attractor position. Remember: Y is typically up in 3D space, X is right, Z is forward/backward.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using strength values that are too high or too low
commonMistakes.explanation: Strength values that are too high cause particles to snap instantly to the attractor. Values that are too low create barely noticeable effects.
commonMistakes.solution: Start with moderate strength values (0.5 to 2.0) and adjust based on desired effect. Higher values for strong pull, lower values for subtle attraction.

commonMistakes.mistake: Placing UpdateAttractorBlock in wrong position in the chain
commonMistakes.explanation: UpdateAttractorBlock modifies particle direction, so it should come before UpdatePositionBlock. Placing it after position updates won't affect movement correctly.
commonMistakes.solution: Chain blocks in order: UpdateAttractorBlock → UpdatePositionBlock → UpdateColorBlock → SystemBlock. Attractor modifies direction, then position uses that direction.

homework: Try different attractor positions (above, below, to the side)
Experiment with different strength values (0.1 to 10.0)
Create multiple attractors by chaining multiple UpdateAttractorBlocks
Combine attractors with gravity for complex motion patterns
Try creating a repeller by using negative strength values (if supported)
